title: Knight Pulse: New Rutgers football hype video and team intro
text:
Knight Pulse: New Rutgers football hype video and team intro Ryan Dunleavy , @rydunleavy 5:39 p.m. EDT October 23, 2015 Rutgers fans are being asked to pound their chest in rhythm with the new team introduction song. (Photo: File photo) 45 CONNECT 36 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PISCATAWAY – As High Point Solutions Stadium comes alive with a sellout crowd Saturday night, it should be easy to measure the pulse of the place. 
In an upstart movement that Rutgers athletics marketing is branding as the “Knight Pulse,” the football team has a new introduction hype video that debuted in its last home game against Michigan State. 
Fans all around the stadium, especially the 10,000 in the student section, are asked to pound their chests in rhythm with the techno-song “The Hum.” 
“I believe the 'Knight Pulse’ has already gone off in the stadium during our last home game and it got an excellent reception,” coach Kyle Flood said. “It’s something that our players had a little fun with and something we try to use to make sure we are riling up the crowd a little bit.” 
The Rutgers football atmosphere will be under an unprecedented spotlight Saturday as the 8 p.m. kickoff against defending national champion No. 1 Ohio State marks the program’s first ever home game broadcast nationally on ABC. 
“This video with the music went over very well with students,” said Geoff Brown, chief marketing officer for Rutgers athletics. “Football is pumped up about it. It really got the fans going quickly and the students going quickly. It was a pretty quick hit.” 
The idea started with an email that Brown received from a fan during the first week of September. Director of fan experience Rob Roselli worked out the specific concept. 
“He linked me the song,” said Brown, who is part of the Rutgers Fan Advisory Board, “and the email literally said, ‘You’ve got to play this at the stadium. The students will go nuts.’” 
Sure enough, Rutgers filmed groups of students pounding their chest at various spots around campus as part of the video. A handful of football players also are seen in the footage. 
Short snippets (like the one above) of the longer video have been teased out through the athletic department’s social media channels. It was played on the stadium’s video board three times last home game. 
“It’s something easy for the students to get into and make some noise,” Brown said. “Now it’s just take it and run with it.” 
Syracuse also began using "The Hum" as part of its crowd hype at the start of this season. 
Within the Big Ten, Wisconsin is famous for its crowd making stadium-rattling noise to the song "Jump Around" at the start of the fourth quarter. 
If the scene Rutgers wants to depict sounds familiar, it’s because it’s a spin-off on a scene from the movie “Wolf of Wall Street,” when Matthew McConaughey is explaining the wild lifestyle he leads to Leonardo DiCaprio. 
“I know Matthew is a big football fan,” Flood said. “I think he is a Texas fan. But I’ll put it out there right now: If Matthew wants to come to the game, I’ll take care of him.” 
Flood is urging fans to be in their seats early. 
“The importance of being there early is I think it energizes the stadium, which ultimately energizes the football team,” he said. 
“I know there is no question that it raises the emotional level of our players when they are out there in warm-ups. The student section has done such a great job of becoming a force within the game. When the game starts, we want them to be warmed up too.”
